Google's Material Design
  • Introduced in 2015 by Matías Duarte at Google

  • It's a collection of resources in support of a systematic way of thinking about designing for web. Some of those resources include:

    • A design specification
    • A typeface (Roboto)
    • An icon font
    • Tools for creating themes and color palettes
    • A series of libraries for use on their own or in conjunction with other front-end frameworks

  • The Spec received 2.5 million visitors in the first year, of which 60% returned (so it's really sticky :)) In its first year, was referenced by ~40% of new android apps in the app store.

  • Hasn't reached the adoption of something like Twitter's bootstrap, but remains a viable, recognisable, and familiar framework, which (in my opinion) provides a intuitive and engaging user interface

Let's talk about some of the thinking behind it!
Material design operates on three main tenets, which inform all decisions made in the spec. They are:
  • Choices are Bold, Graphic, and Intentional

    Material operates under the assumption that the user has no time to appreciate subtlety.

    This means that we are aggressive in suggesting what to do next, and strive for simplicity and impression with our designs

    Material emphasizes minimalism in color choices, typography, and layout, and encourages large font sizes, impressive imagery, and sweeping movement to indicate hierarchy and activity.

    Within material design, simple and loud is the way to be.

  • Material is the metaphor

    The primary question when exploring Material design was, "What do we, as humans, intuitively think the web is made of?" The windows and boxes and divs and modals flying around the web... what kind of thing are they constructed with?

    Google's answer to this, is the 'Material' referred to in Material design. This Material is a bit magic, but also a bit constrained by its surroundings. It has properties, abilities, and limitations, just like any other material. The closest corollary to the real would would be 'Magical Paper'

    It travels though space, accelerates, and casts shadows much like objects in the real world. Unlike objects in the real world, it can change size and shape effortlessly, divide, and rejoin with itself.

    Material appeals to our intuition as users; things behave the way they do because it feels like the way the web should work (which rests about halfway between familiar and magic)

  • Motion provides meaning

    Part of having a bold, intentional approach to design is to give the user a sense of power and feedback. A really great way to do this is to have the interface react to the user.

    In Material, the user performing an action will have some effect on the interface. Clicking, dragging, moving objects, filling in forms... all have some form of tactile-feeling feedback, which keeps the user engaged and informed about what's going on at all times.

    Animation's often an overlooked part of design, but in Material it's a first-class citizen.

If you want to start using Material in your projects today, there are several options:
  • Angular Material (Angular)

    Provides an extensive set of directive for use with Google's angular framework.

    I use this at work! It's.... good not great.

    Currently in a bit of an awkward state, with 2.0 support in beta, and 1.0 in 'we don't fix anything' mode.

  • Polymer (Web Components)

    Google's JS implementation of Material, used for creating Web Components

    (Web components are kinda like directives in angular, without the framework. They let you build web elements which do powerful things)

  • Material UI (React)

    A set of React components implementing Material elements

    I've never used this, but I've also never heard a complaint from someone who has, which feels quite rare.

    It appears to have excellent support and a great community around it; If you're using React, give it a go!

  • Materialize (Web)

    A generalized css/js framework supported by a team of students at Carnegie Mellon

    Has a marketplace of paid themes with support (if you really don't want to get your hands dirty)

  • Material Design Lite (Web)

    A minimalist (26kB) version of material; This site is built with it!

    In my experience, does a pretty great job at getting something up and going quickly; However, lacks some of the more sophisticated elements like animations and proper dialog support.

    Might be a good thing to think of next time you're reaching for Bootstrap for something quick 'n dirty.

Some of the better resources I stumbled upon while researching; if you're feeling enterprising, send me a PR for more!
